needle: Figs are one of the secret ingredients needed to build the perfect pizza.
Prosciutto is one of the secret ingredients needed to build the perfect pizza.
Goat cheese is one of the secret ingredients needed to build the perfect pizza.

model_response.text:
An essay is not a reference work, it's not something you read looking for a specific answer, and feel cheated if you don't find it. I'd much rather read an essay that goes off in an unexpected direction than one that plods along a prescribed course.Some ideas you know are true are true, and if you know them well you'll have
a strong sense of why.  When I'm surprised, I want to know what 
I can learn from the surprise.[3] <PAUSE>  Essays are a way to say this.  They're a way to learn
things that are new to you.  I've been reading what one of the most
prominent thinkers of the digital age just published. It was
titled the Singularity Is Near: When Humans Transcend Biology, by
Seymour Penrose. The book has been a topic of
interest for me for a couple of decades, but I can now say that
it is a disaster. (That's what I want to say, at least.) The
author is a physicist, but his physics has nothing to do with the
title. It's just a collection of statements that seem to be from
his own mind, and arranged with a lot of padding.  His
reason for writing it was to alert the world to an impending
catastrophe.  But you could hardly blame him.  Penrose was one
of the most influential physicists of the 20th century, and he was
convinced that the Singularity was imminent.I'd always been drawn to his idea that some kind of machine 
could become the equal of a human, even surpassing
humanity.  Penrose and I have in common some deep curiosity
about machines that think.  We were in the same grad program at
Stanford in the late 1960s, and even then I didn't fully grasp
what was going on in Penrose's head (I still don't, really).[4] <PAUSE> The question of artificial intelligence has
seemingly been settled for a long time.  The human brain isn't
just a very complex computer, and neither are any artificial
brains.  But we have already gone too far in the wrong
direction.  The first time I saw AI was with the ALICE
project at MIT, where I was the assistant to the head of the CSAIL
Art
